lesson.name: Lesson 5.6 Teacher Guide: Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation

page.title: 5.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In this lesson, students examine the meaning of negative exponents in context. In these cases, time \(t\) is the independent variable, and \(t=0\) corresponds to a particular moment when a quantity is first measured. In these situations, a value of \(t\) that is less than 0 corresponds to a time before the initial measurement, while a value of \(t\) that is greater than 0 refers to a time after the measurement. Students write equations given a table, and then they use those equations to answer questions, which requires working with negative values representing time. In one case, students also produce a graph. As with many other activities in this unit, the mathematical work is grounded and interpreted in a context.

Students learn to convert fluently between decimal form and scientific notation. They will solve problems in context involving numbers in decimal form and scientific notation. They will combine what they have learned using negative exponents to find the solution to a real-world problem in scientific notation.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Interpret a negative exponent in equations that represent exponential growth and decay.
  • Derive equations that represent exponential growth and decay in real-world problems.
  • Select a proper window while graphing an equation they derived from a real-world problem involving exponential decay.
  • Fluently convert between decimal form and scientific notation.
  • Apply measurements in scientific notation and decimal form to solve a problem in a real-world situation.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Describe the meaning of a negative exponent in equations that represent exponential growth and decay.
  • Write equations that represent exponential growth and decay to solve problems.
  • Graph an equation that represents exponential decay to solve a problem.
  • Convert numbers between decimal form and scientific notation.
  • Use scientific notation to solve problems arising from real-world situations.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage
  • A9(B) interpret the meaning of the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in exponential functions of the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) in real-world problems
  • A9(C) write exponential functions in the form \(f(x) = ab^x\) (where \(b\) is a rational number) to describe problems arising from mathematical and real-world situations, including growth and decay
  • A9(D) graph exponential functions that model growth and decay and identify key features, including \(y\)-intercept and asymptote, in mathematical and real-world problems
  • Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.
  • Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.
  • Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

  • 5.6.1: Checking Exponent Rules
  • 5.6.2: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth
    • 5.6.2: Self Check
    • 5.6.2: Additional Resources
  • 5.6.3: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay
    • 5.6.3: Self Check
    • 5.6.3: Additional Resources
  • 5.6.4: Using Scientific Notation
    • 5.6.4: Self Check
    • 5.6.4: Additional Resources
  • 5.6.5: Applying Scientific Notation
    • 5.6.5: Self Check
    • 5.6.5: Additional Resources
  • 5.6.6: Interpreting Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 5.6.7: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Graphing technology

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • equation
  • scientific notation

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their grit.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Me to Me
  • Success Story

You can find other tips located here in the Grit Playbook from Character Lab.

page.title: 5.6.1: Checking Exponent Rules
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm-up prepares students to work with expressions involving negative exponents. Students have studied exponents and their properties in grade 8 and encountered negative exponents at that time. The goal here is to review the fact that for integer exponents \(m\) and \(n\) and a non-zero base \(b\), this property holds: \(b^m\cdot b^n=b^{m+n}\).

Student Activity

How would you rewrite each of the following as an equivalent expression with a single exponent?

  1. \(2^4\cdot 2^0\)

    Answer: \(2^4\)

  2. \(2^4\cdot 2^{-1}\)

    Answer: \(2^3\)

  3. \(2^4\cdot 2^{-3}\)

    Answer: \(2^1\)

  4. \(2^4\cdot 2^{-4}\)
    Answer: \(2^0\)

Activity Synthesis

Review, if needed, the conventions that \(2^0=1\) and \(2^{-1}=\frac12\), emphasizing that these conventions guarantee that \(2^a\cdot 2^b=2^{a+b}\) for any two integers \(a\) and \(b\).

page.title: 5.6.2: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

Up to this point in the unit, students have written and interpreted equations representing exponential change that were meaningful for non-negative input values. In this lesson, they interpret the meaning of a negative value in a context. The independent variable is time, \(t\), so negative values of \(t\) refer to times before \(t\) is 0.

For the last question, to find the time when the coral had the given volume, students may:

  • Calculate the values of \(y\) when \(t\) is –3, –4, –5, etc. (i.e., extend the table of values, if they previously created one) until they reach 37.5 or a value close to it.
  • Repeatedly divide by 2 (or multiply by \(\frac12\)) the value of \(y\) when \(t\) is –2 until it approaches or hits 37.5.
  • Use the equation \(1,200\cdot 2^t=37.5\) to find the value of \(2^t\) and then reason about \(t\) from there.

Look for students using these or other strategies so they can share later.

Making graphing technology available gives students an opportunity to choose appropriate tools strategically.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of 2. Encourage them to think quietly about the questions before discussing with their partner. Creating a table or spreadsheet may help students organize the work in the second question. If needed, encourage students to do so.

Support for English Language Learners

To help students make sense of the language of exponential situations, start by displaying the task statement: “A marine biologist estimates that a structure of coral has a volume of 1,200 cubic centimeters and that its volume doubles each year.” Give students 1–2 minutes to write their own mathematical questions about the situation. Invite students to share their questions with the class, and then reveal the activity’s questions. Listen for and amplify any questions referring to the value of \(t\), especially those wondering about time in the past. This will build student understanding and interpretation of the language used to represent negative exponents.


Support for Students with Disabilities

Begin the activity with concrete or familiar contexts. Encourage students to create a timeline next to their tables, selecting a starting point year for zero and then labeling the years correlated with the positive exponents prior to labeling years associated with negative exponents.


Student Activity

A marine biologist estimates that a structure of coral has a volume of 1,200 cubic centimeters and that its volume doubles each year.

  1. Write an equation of the form \(y=a\cdot b^t\) representing the relationship, where \(t\) is time in years since the coral was measured and \(y\) is volume of coral in cubic centimeters. (You need to figure out what numbers \(a\) and \(b\) are in this situation.)

    Answer: \(y=1,200\cdot 2^t\)

  1. Find the volume of the coral when \(t\) is 5, 1, 0, –1, and –2. Note that when \(t = -1\), this represents one year before the marine biologist made the original estimate.

time (years)

5

1

0

–1

–2

volume of coral (cubic centimeters)

 

 

 

 

 

Answer:

time (years)

5

1

0

–1

–2

volume of coral (cubic centimeters)

38,400

2,400

1,200

600

300

  1. What does it mean, in this situation, when \(t\) is –2?

    Answer: This represents the time 2 years before the scientist made the estimate of 1,200 cubic centimeters.

  1. In a certain year, the volume of the coral is 37.5 cubic centimeters. Which year is this? Explain your reasoning.

    Answer: \(t\) is –5, or 5 years before the scientist made the estimate of 1,200 cubic centimeters.

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may struggle to think of how to start finding the values for \(a\) and \(b\). Suggest that they make a table of corresponding values of \(t\) and \(y\), and think about starting with \(t\) and calculating \(y\).

They may also struggle with understanding a negative value for \(t\) referring to years. Emphasize that a value of \(t = -1\) represents the time 1 year before the estimate was made. Ask what a value of \(t = -4\) represents.

Activity Synthesis

Review how students found an equation, \(y=1,200\cdot 2^t\), to represent the volume of coral. Make sure that they recall that the 1,200 represents the 1,200 cubic centimeters of coral when it was first measured, and the 2 indicates the doubling of its volume each year.

Select students to share their interpretations of negative values of \(t\) and how they found the value of \(t\) when given a volume. Ask questions such as:

  • “In this situation, what does it mean to say that when \(t\) is –3, \(y\) is \(1,200\cdot 2^{-3}\) or 150?” (3 years before the coral was measured to be 1,200 cubic centimeters, its volume was 150 cubic centimeters.)
  • “How did you estimate or find \(t\) when the volume of the coral was 37.5 cubic centimeters?”

It may be helpful to display a graph of \(y=1,200\cdot 2^t\), such as the one embedded in the digital version of these materials. Display the graph (either with or without the points from the table plotted) and ask students to identify the volume of coral when \(t\) is –3 and the time when the volume of coral is 37.5 cubic centimeters.

If using the digital applet, consider initially turning off the function and the point, and hiding the expression list. Ask students to gesture at points on the graph corresponding to questions in the activity. Then, turn on the function and the point for demonstration. Remember that if you click on a plotted point, its coordinates are revealed.

5.6.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION: 

Using the equation \(p=10,000\cdot 2^d\), find the value of \(p\) when \(d = -2\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

2,500

That’s correct! Check yourself: The expression \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}=2,500\).

20,000

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the value when \(d =1\). Evaluate the expression when \(d=-2\). \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}\). The answer is 2,500.

5,000

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the value when \(d=-1\). Find the value when \(d=-2\). Evaluate the expression \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}\). The answer is 2,500.

40,000

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the value when \(d=2\). Find the value when \(d=-2\). Evaluate the expression \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}\). The answer is 2,500.

5.6.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth

Let’s look at a problem involving an exponential growth equation and negative exponents.

A forest fire has been burning for several days. The burned area, in acres, is given by the equation \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\), where \(d\) is the number of days since the area of the fire was first measured.

  1. Let’s complete the table.

    2. \(d\), days since first measurement

    \(y\), acres burned since fire started

    0

    		 a. _____

    –1

    		 b. _____

    –2

    		 c. _____

    –3

    		 d. _____

    –5

    		 e. _____

    a. _____
    Substitute 0 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^0\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 1\)
    \(y=4,800\)
    Answer: 4,800

    b. _____
    Substitute –1 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-1}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac12\)
    \(y=2,400\)
    Answer: 2,400

    c. _____
    Substitute –2 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-2}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac14\)
    \(y=1,200\)
    Answer: 1,200

    d. _____
    Substitute –3 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-3}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac18\)
    \(y=600\)
    Answer: 600

    e. _____
    Substitute –5 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-5}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac1{32}\)
    \(y=150\)
    Answer: 150


    \(d\), days since first measurement

    \(y\), acres burned since fire started

    0

    4,800

    –1

    2,400

    –2

    1,200

    –3

    600

    –5

    150

  2. Look at the value of \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\) when \(d=-1\). What does it tell you about the area burned in the fire?

    3. Answer: It tells you that 1 day before the first measurement, 2,400 acres had burned.

  3. How much area had the fire burned a week before it measured 4,800 acres? Explain your reasoning.

    4. Answer: Substitute –7 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-7}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac1{128}\)
    \(y=37.5\)

    37.5 acres had burned a week before the fire measured 4,800 acres. The solution is found by substituting –7 for \(d\) since that represents 7 days before the first measurement of 4,800 acres.

Try It: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth

The value of a home in 2015 was $400,000. Its value has doubled each decade.

  1. If \(v\) is the value of the home, in dollars, write an equation for \(v\) in terms of \(d\), the number of decades since 2015.
  2. What is \(v\) when \(d=-1\)? What does this value mean?
  3. What is \(v\) when \(d=-3\)? What does this value mean?

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to solve this exponential growth problem using negative exponents:

  1. \(v=400,000\cdot 2^d\)

  2. Substitute –1 for \(d\).

    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^d\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^{-1}\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot\frac12\)
    \(v=200,000\)

    So, \(v = 200,000\) when \(d=-1\); This means the home had a value of 200,000 in 2005, one decade before 2015.

  3. Substitute –3 for \(d\).

    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^d\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^{-3}\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot\frac18\)
    \(v=50,000\)

    So, \(v = 50,000\) when \(d=-3\); This means the home had a value of 50,000 in 1985, three decades before 2015.

page.title: 5.6.3: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

In this activity, students use a description and table of values to write an equation that represents them. Then, they interpret the equation for negative values of the exponent and produce a graph. They also interpret the numbers in the equation in terms of the context.

For the final question, only an estimate is possible. Expect different answers that range between 2 and 3 hours before the medicine was measured because a more precise answer cannot be given right now. Look for students who use the graph and try to extend it to values between integer hours. Invite them to share during the discussion.

Launch

If students continue to use graphing technology while working on this task, they are likely to enter their equation and see a smooth curve. It is not the intention that they try to sketch a curve at this time. Draw their attention to the instructions that say to plot the points.

Support for Students with Disabilities

Provide access to graph paper or to tools and assistive technologies, such as graphing calculators or graphing software.


Student Activity

A person took some medicine but does not remember how much. Concerned that she took too much, she has a blood test every hour for several hours.

\(t\), time (hours)

\(m\), medicine (mg)

–3

  

–1

  

0

100

1

50

2

25

  1.   Answer the following questions.
    1. Time \(t\) is measured in hours since the blood test, and amount of medicine in her body, \(m\), is measured in milligrams. What is the decay factor? That is, what is \(b\) in an equation of the form \(m=a\cdot b^t\)? What is \(a\)?
      Answer: \(b=\frac12\), \(a=100\)

    2. Find the amounts of medicine in the patient’s body when \(t\) is –1 and –3.
      Answer:

      \(t\), time (hours)

      \(m\), medicine (mg)

      –3

      800

      –1

      200

      0

      100

      1

      50

      2

      25

  2. What do \(t=0\) and \(t=-3\) mean in this context?
    Answer: \(t=0\) means the time the doctor did the first blood test. \(t=-3\) means 3 hours before the doctor did the first test.

  3. The medicine was taken when \(t\) is –5. Assuming the person did not have any of the medication in her body beforehand, how much medicine did the patient take?
    Answer: 3,200 mg. Each hour this is cut in half. After being halved 5 times, it leaves 100 mg, the amount of medicine in the person's body when \(t=0\).

  4. Plot the points whose coordinates are shown in the table. Make sure to draw and label tick marks on the axes.


    5. Answer:

  5. Based on your graph, when do you think the patient will have:
    1. 500 mg of medicine remaining in her body
      Answer: Sample response: Between 2 and 3 hours before the patient first had her blood tested

    2. no medicine remaining in her body
      Answer: Sample responses:
      • Sometime after 10 hours. The amount of medicine falls below 0.1 mg after about 10 hours and might be too small to be detectable after that point.
      • Eventually, all of the medicine will be out of the patient’s body (but the mathematical model for the amount of medicine does not reach 0).

Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

Without evaluating them, describe each of the following quantities as close to 0, close to 1, or much larger than 1.

  1. \(\frac1{1-2^{-10}}\)

    2. Answer: close to 1

  2. \(\frac{2^{10}}{2^{10}+1}\)

    3. Answer: close to 1

  3. \(\frac{2^{-10}}{2^{10}+1}\)

    4. Answer: close to 0

  4. \(\frac{1-2^{-10}}{2^{10}}\)

    5. Answer: close to 0

  5. \(\frac{1+2^{10}}{2^{-10}}\)

    6. Answer: much larger than 1

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may struggle with understanding the negative time values. It may help to give clock values to the numbers. For example, the first blood test was done at 5:00 p.m. \((t=0)\). Ask students what \(t\) would be when it is 6:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. It is important throughout this entire lesson to emphasize that time is not typically negative, but in this case is emphasizing events that happened prior to initial measurement.

Activity Synthesis

Ask students how they labeled the axes on the graph. For the domain, it needs to include times from 3 hours before the medicine was measured to 2 hours after. (Students may also choose to include 5 hours before the first measurement.) The vertical axis should include 0 up to at least 800 (higher if students include the value for \(t=-5\) in the table).

Use the last question about when there was 500 mg of medicine to begin a discussion about values between integer hours. Elicit from students how the graph might look if we consider non-integer time values. If students still have access to graphing technology for this activity, they can enter their equation and see the curve for themselves.

Consider displaying the following graphs for all to see. Explain that if the amount of medicine in the bloodstream is plotted at time intervals smaller than 1 hour, the graph may look like the first graph. We sometimes graph a relationship where a quantity changes continuously using a curve, as in the second graph. Students will have more opportunities to consider non-integer domain values in upcoming lessons.

To follow up on the last question, consider discussing: How long could the decrease by half go on? Is there a point at which it is no longer practical or reasonable to use the mathematical model?

5.6.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION: 

A census of hemlock trees is taken in a national park. The rangers have found that only \(\frac45\) of the population has survived each year. The data are shown in the table. Find the number of hemlocks that were in the park 2 years before the census was taken.

\(y\), years since census

\(h\), number of hemlocks

–2

  

0

64,000

1

51,200

3

32,768

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

156,250

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the solution for 4 years before the census was taken. The equation to represent this situation is

\(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\). The solution is found by substituting –2 for \(y\). The answer is 100,000.

125,000

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the solution for 3 years before the census was taken. The equation to represent this situation is

\(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\). The solution is found by substituting –2 for \(y\). The answer is 100,000.

80,000

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the solution for 1 year before the census was taken. Find the solution 2 years before the census was taken. The equation to represent this situation is

\(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\). The solution is found by substituting –2 for \(y\). The answer is 100,000.

100,000

That’s correct! Check yourself: The equation to represent this situation is \(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\).

5.6.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay

Let’s look at a problem involving an exponential decay equation and negative exponents.

A scientist records the population of a bacterial population in a petri dish. The data are shown in the table.


\(d\), days since first test

\(b\), number of bacteria

–3

  

–1

  

0

40,000

1

20,000

3

5,000

The number of days \(d\) since the first test corresponds with the number of bacteria, \(b\), estimated to be alive in the petri dish.

  1. What is the decay factor? That is, what is \(f\) in an equation of the form \(b=n\cdot f^d\)? What is the starting population, \(n\), on the first day of testing?

    Since the number of bacteria found on day 0 is 40,000, then \(n = 40,000\). Since after each day, the number of bacteria is cut in half, then the decay factor, \(f\), is \(\frac12\).

    The equation to represent this situation is \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\).

  2. What do \(d=-1\) and \(d=-3\) mean in this context?

    \(d=0\) means the day the first test is taken. \(d=-1\) means 1 day before the scientist did the first test. \(d=-3\) means 3 days before the scientist did the first test.

  3. How many bacteria were present 1 day before the first test?

    Substitute –1 for \(d\) in the equation \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\).

    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^{-1}\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot 2\)
    \(b=80,000\)

    There were 80,000 bacteria in the petri dish 1 day before the test.

  4. Assume the peak of the bacterial population was 3 days before the first test. How many bacteria were present at the peak of the population?

    Substitute –3 for \(d\) in the equation \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\).

    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^{-3}\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot 8\)
    \(b=320,000\)

    There were 320,000 bacteria in the petri dish 3 days before the test at the peak of the population.

Try It: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay

An investor has tracked the value of a particular investment since 2016 that has depreciated over time. The data are shown in the table.


\(y\), years since 2016

\(v\), value of investment ($)

–2

  

–1

  

0

36,000

1

12,000

2

4,000

  1. What is the equation that represents this situation?
  1. What do \(y=-1\) and \(y=-2\) mean in this context?
  1. If the value of the investment was at its highest in 2014, what was the maximum value of the investment?

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve this exponential growth problem using negative exponents:

Solution

  1. The equation that represents this situation is \(v=36,000\cdot\left(\frac13\right)^y\). The value of the investment in year 0 is $36,000, and the decay factor is \(\frac13\).
  1. \(y=-1\) means 1 year before 2016, which is 2015. \(y=-2\) means 2 years before 2016, which is 2014.
  1. The maximum value of the investment was $324,000.

    \(v=36,000\cdot\left(\frac13\right)^y\)
    \(v=36,000\cdot\left(\frac13\right)^{-2}\)
    \(v=36,000\cdot 9\)
    \(v=324,000\)

page.title: 5.6.4: Using Scientific Notation
page.contents:
Activity

Student Activity

  1. How would you write each of the following numbers in scientific notation?

Decimal Form

Scientific Notation

0.00000654

  

0.0000947

  

683,000

  

0.022

  

5,200

  

0.000352

  

Answer:

Decimal Form

Scientific Notation

0.00000654

\(6.54\times10^{-6}\)

0.0000947

\(9.47\times10^{-5}\)

683,000

\(6.83\times10^5\)

0.022

\(2.2\times10^{-2}\)

5,200

\(5.2\times10^3\)

0.000352

\(3.52\times10^{-4}\)

  1. How would you write each of the following scientific notation values in decimal form?

Scientific Notation

Decimal Form

\(7.26\times10^{-4}\)

  

\(3.32\times10^{-2}\)

   

\(9.4\times10^6\)

  

\(8.87\times10^{-1}\)

  

\(6.395\times10^4\)

  

\(4.0\times10^{-3}\)

  

Answer:

Scientific Notation

Decimal Form

\(7.26\times10^{-4}\)

0.000726

\(3.32\times10^{-2}\)

0.0332

\(9.4\times10^6\)

9,400,000

\(8.87\times10^{-1}\)

0.887

\(6.395\times10^4\)

63,950

\(4.0\times10^{-3}\)

0.004

Video: Converting between Scientific Notation and Decimal Form

Watch the following video to learn more about rewriting scientific notation in decimal form and decimal form in scientific notation.



5.6.4: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION: 

Which of the following equations is true?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(7.64\times 10^3 = 76,400\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying by \(10^3\) means multiplying by 1000.

\(7.64\times 1000 = 7,640\). The answer is \(8.5\times 10^{-4} = 0.00085\).

\(9.11\times 10^5 = 91,100\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying by \(10^5\) means multiplying by 100,000. \(9.11\times 100,000 = 911,000\). The answer is \(8.5\times 10^{-4} = 0.00085\).

\(8.5\times 10^{-4} = 0.00085\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiplying by \(10^{-4}\) means dividing by 10,000. The values are equivalent.

\(2.36\times 10^{-5} = 0.00000236\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying by \(10^{-5}\) means dividing by 100,000. \(2.36\times 10^{-5} = 0.0000236\). The answer is \(8.5\times 10^{-4} = 0.00085\).

5.6.4: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who would benefit from it.

Using Scientific Notation

Working with very large or very small numbers can be awkward. Since our number system is base ten, we can use powers of ten to rewrite very large or very small numbers to make them easier to work with. Consider the numbers 4,000 and 0.004.

Using place value, we can rewrite the numbers 4,000 and 0.004. We know that 4,000 means \(4\times 1,000\) and 0.004 means \(4\times\frac1{1000}\).

If we write the 1,000 as a power of ten in exponential form, we can rewrite these numbers in this way:


4,000

\(4\times 1,000\)

\(4\times 10^3\)


0.004

\(4\times\frac1{1000}\)

\(4\times\frac1{10^3}\)

\(4\times 10^{-3}\)

When a number is written as a product of two numbers, where the first factor is a number greater than or equal to 1 but less than 10, and the second factor is a power of 10 written in exponential form, it is said to be in scientific notation.

A number is expressed in scientific notation when it is of what form?

\(a\times 10^n\) where \(1 \leq│a│< 10\) and \(n\) is an integer.

It is customary in scientific notation to use × as the multiplication sign, even though we avoid using this sign elsewhere in algebra.


To convert a decimal to scientific notation:

Step 1. Move the decimal point so that the first factor is greater than or equal to 1 but less than 10.

Step 2. Count the number of decimal places, \(n\), that the decimal point was moved.

Step 3. Write the number as a product with a power of 10. If the original number is

  • greater than 1, the power of 10 will be \(10^n\).
  • between 0 and 1, the power of 10 will be \(10^{−n}\).

Step 4. Check.


Example: Write in scientific notation:

  1. 37,000
    Answer:
  2. 0.0052
    Answer:
To convert scientific notation to decimal form:

Step 1. Determine the exponent, \(n\), on the factor of 10.

Step 2. Move the decimal \(n\) places, adding zeros if needed.

  • If the exponent is positive, move the decimal point \(n\) places to the right.
  • If the exponent is negative, move the decimal point \(n\) places to the left.

Step 3. Check.

Example: Write in decimal form:

  1. \(6.2 \times 10^3\)
    Answer:

  2. \(-8.9\times10^{-2}\)
    Answer:

Try It: Using Scientific Notation

Write in scientific notation.

  1. 65,000,000
  2. 0.00034

Write in decimal form.

  1. \(5.3 \times10^5 \)
  2. \(4.25 \times10^{-3}\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to write the numbers:

  1. \( 6.5 \times10^7 \)
  2. \( 3.4\times10^{-4} \)
  3. 530,000
  4. 0.00425

page.title: 5.6.5: Applying Scientific Notation
page.contents:
Activity

Student Activity

  1. A biologist receives bird population estimates for different parks. The estimates are shown in the table. Work with your partner to arrange these estimates in order from least to greatest.

    2. Park

    Bird Population

    Shady Elm

    \(7.5\times10^3\)

    Westcott Park

    105,000

    Brighton Park

    \(4.5\times10^2\)

    Red Elk

    22,300

    Bear Park

    \(1.1\times10^5\)

    Daniels Park

    3,300

    Blue Spruce

    \(1.25\times10^4\)

    Yellow Jay Park

    \(2.25\times10^4\)

    Answer:

  • Brighton Park, \(4.5\times10^2\)
  • Daniels Park, 3,300
  • Shady Elm, \(7.5\times10^3\)
  • Blue Spruce, \(1.25\times10^4\)
  • Red Elk, 22,300
  • Yellow Jay Park, \(2.25\times10^4\)
  • Westcott Park, 105,000
  • Bear Park, \(1.1\times10^5\)

  • Enrico weighs the small objects shown for a science project. Work with your partner to arrange these weights in order from heaviest to lightest.

    • Object

    Weight (lb)

    grain of sand

    \(1.4\times10^{-4}\)

    grain of pollen

    0.00001014

    one drop of water

    0.00011

    a feather

    \(1.8\times10^{-5}\)

    one kernel of corn

    \(1.1\times10^{-3}\)

    house fly

    \(3.08\times10^{-5}\)

    Answer:

    • one kernel of corn, \(1.1\times10^{-3}\)
    • grain of sand, \(1.4\times10^{-4}\)
    • one drop of water, 0.00011
    • house fly, \(3.08\times10^{-5}\)
    • a feather, \(1.8\times10^{-5}\)
    • grain of pollen, 0.00001014

  • What do you notice when comparing numbers in scientific notation with different negative exponents?
    Answer: If both exponents are negative, then the number with the smaller absolute value exponent is the larger number. For example, the number with the exponent –3 is larger than the number with the exponent –4.

    • 5.6.5: Self Check

    After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

    QUESTION: 

    Which of the numbers shown is the greatest?

    ANSWERS

    FEEDBACK

    0.0065

    Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Compare the numbers in the same form. 0.0065 is equivalent to \(6.5\times10^{-3}\). This is not the greatest number. The answer is \(7.2\times10^{-3}\).

    \(7.2\times10^{-3}\)

    That’s correct! Check yourself: The number \(7.2\times10^{-3}\) is the largest value. It is equivalent to 0.0072.

    0.00084

    Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Compare the numbers in the same form. 0.00084 is equivalent to \(8.4\times10^{-4}\). \(10^{-4}\) is less than \(10^{-3}\). The answer is \(7.2\times10^{-3}\).

    \(9.6\times10^{-5}\)

    Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(10^{-5}\) is less than \(10^{-4}\). \(9.6\times10^{-5}\) is equivalent to 0.000096. The answer is \(7.2\times10^{-3}\).

    5.6.5: Additional Resources

    The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to the content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

    Applying Scientific Notation

    Let’s look at how to solve a real-world problem involving scientific notation.

    The specimens below are measured lengths of different tiny animals. Arrange them in order from shortest to longest.


    Specimen

    Length (m)

    A

    \(7.0\times10^{-3}\)

    B

    0.0000847

    C

    0.00022

    D

    \(1.8\times10^{-4}\)

    E

    \(8.92\times10^{-3}\)

    F

    \(6.03\times10^{-2}\)

    To solve this problem, we can convert all of the measurements to decimal form or standard form.

    Let’s convert all measurements to decimal form from scientific notation.


    Specimen

    Length (m)

    A

    \(7.0\times10^{-3} = 0.007\)

    B

    0.0000847

    C

    0.00022

    D

    \(1.8\times10^{-4} = 0.00018\)

    E

    \(8.92\times10^{-3} = 0.00892\)

    F

    \(6.03\times10^{-2} = 0.0603\)

    We can now arrange the decimal values in order from shortest to longest:

    B, D, C, A, E, F

    Let’s convert each length into scientific notation and check our answer.


    Specimen

    Length (m)

    A

    \(7.0\times10^{-3}\)

    B

    \(0.0000847 = 8.47\times 10^{-5}\)

    C

    \(0.00022 = 2.2 \times 10^{-4}\)

    D

    \(1.8\times10^{-4}\)

    E

    \(8.92\times10^{-3}\)

    F

    \(6.03\times10^{-2}\)

    The negative exponent with the largest absolute value represents the smallest number, so B is the shortest length.

    The negative exponent with the smallest absolute value represents the largest number, so F is the longest length.

    When the exponents are equal, compare the decimal part of the number.

    The order B, D, C, A, E, F is correct from shortest to longest length.

    Try It: Applying Scientific Notation

    The measurements in the table are sample wavelengths for the given types of waves. Arrange them in order from shortest to longest.


    Color

    Wavelength (m)

    red light

    \(7.0\times10^{-7}\)

    blue light

    0.00000045

    infrared light

    \(5.0\times10^{-4}\)

    ultraviolet light

    \(2.0\times10^{-9}\)

    microwaves

    \(1.5\times10^{-1}\)

    radio waves

    2.1

    Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

    Solution

    Here is how to arrange the measurements from shortest to longest:

    Let’s convert the values for blue light and radio waves into scientific notation to compare all the values.

    blue light = \(0.00000045 = 4.5\times 10^{-7}\)

    radio waves = \(2.1 = 2.1\times 10^0\)

    So, from shortest to longest the wavelengths are:

    ultraviolet light, \(2.0\times10^{-9}\)
    blue light, \(4.5\times10^{-7}\)
    red light, \(7.0\times10^{-7}\)
    infrared light, \(5.0\times10^{-4}\)
    microwaves, \(1.5\times10^{-1}\)
    radio waves, \(2.1\times10^0\)

page.title: 5.6.6: Interpreting Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

The equation \(p=5,000\cdot2^t\) represents the population of an invasive fish species in a large lake, \(t\) years since 2005, when the fish population in the lake was first surveyed.

  1. What was the population in 2005?
    Answer: 5,000, because \(5,000\cdot 2^0=5,000\).

  2. What is this value of the population in 2005 in scientific notation?
    Answer: \(5.0\times 10^3\)

  3. For this model, what does it mean when \(t\) is –2?
    Answer: It means 2 years before 2005, which is 2003.

  4. For \( t=-2\), is the fish population more or less than 1,000? How do you know?
    Answer: More than 1,000. For \(t=-2\), \(5,000\cdot 2^{-2}=1,250\).

  5. Write the value of the fish population when \(t=-2\) in scientific notation.
    Answer: \(1.25\times 10^3 \)

Response to Student Thinking

Points to emphasize

If students struggle to interpret negative exponents, use student work from this cool-down to guide a brief discussion on the topic in a subsequent lesson.

page.title: 5.6.7: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

Use the following passage to answer questions 1–3.

In a newly formed swamp, it is estimated that there are 500 mosquitoes. The population is estimated to double each day.

  1. Let \(m\) represent the total population of mosquitoes and \(d\) represent the number of days that have passed since the first estimate. What is the equation that represents the growth of the mosquito population?
    1. \(m=d\cdot 500^2\)
    2. \(m=2\cdot 500^d\)
    3. \(m=500\cdot 2^d\)
    4. \(m=500\cdot d^2\)

Answer: c. \(m=500\cdot 2^d\)

  1. What does \(d=-2\) represent in this context?
    1. This represents 2 days before the first estimate was taken.
    2. This represents the day before the first estimate was taken.
    3. This represents the day the first estimate was taken.
    4. This represents 2 days after the first estimate was taken.

Answer: a. This represents 2 days before the first estimate was taken.

  1. What is the estimated number of mosquitoes that were in the new swamp 1 day before the estimate was taken?
    1. 500
    2. 250
    3. 1,000
    4. 125

Answer: b. 250

Use the following passage to answer questions 4–6.

A desert pond is slowly drying up. The average volume of the pond is shown in the table. The first year it was measured, the average volume was determined to be 40,000 liters.


    \(y\), years

    \(v\), volume (liters)

    –4

    		  

    –2

    		  

    0

    40,000

    1

    20,000

    3

    5,000

  1. Which equation represents the pond’s water loss?
    1. \(y=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^v\)
    2. \(v=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^y\)
    3. \(v=20,000\cdot\left(\frac14\right)^y\)
    4. \(v=\frac12\cdot\left(40,000\right)^y\)

Answer: b. \(v=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^y\)

  1. What does \(y=-2\) represent in this context?
    1. the time it took for the pond to shrink by a factor of 2
    2. the first time the volume was measured
    3. the time 2 years after the first time the volume was measured
    4. the time 2 years before the first time the volume was measured

Answer: d. the time 2 years before the first time the volume was measured

  1. What was the average volume of the pond 4 years before the first time the volume was measured?
    1. 320,000 liters
    2. 160,000 liters
    3. 80,000 liters
    4. 640,000 liters

Answer: d. 640,000 liters

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to 6,350,000 in scientific notation?
    1. \(6.35\times 10^4\)
    2. \(6.35\times 10^5\)
    3. \(6.35\times 10^6\)
    4. \(6.35\times 10^7\)

Answer: c. \(6.35\times 10^6\)

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to 0.00032 in scientific notation?
    1. \(3.2\times 10^{-3}\)
    2. \(3.2\times 10^{-4}\)
    3. \(3.2\times 10^{-5}\)
    4. \(3.2\times 10^{-6}\)

Answer: b. \(3.2\times 10^{-4}\)

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(7.24\times 10^3\) in decimal form?
    1. 7,240
    2. 724
    3. 72,400
    4. 724,000

Answer: a. 7,240

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(5.47\times 10^{-5}\) in decimal form?
    1. 0.00547
    2. 0.0000547
    3. 0.00000547
    4. 0.000547

Answer: b. 0.0000547

  1. Which of the following correctly orders these values from greatest to least?

    2. Value R

    0.00161

    Value S

    \(6.35\times 10^{-3}\)

    Value T

    0.000541

    Value U

    \(7.23\times 10^{-4}\)

    1. Value S, Value R, Value T, Value U
    2. Value R, Value S, Value T, Value U
    3. Value S, Value R, Value U, Value T
    4. Value R, Value S, Value U, Value T

Answer: c. Value S, Value R, Value U, Value T

page.title: 5.6.8: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
Equations are useful not only for representing relationships that change exponentially, but also for answering questions about these situations. In this lesson, students used data from a table to construct equations representing exponential growth and decay. They used these equations to answer questions given the context of the situation.

To help students, review the following points:

  • We looked at some situations where negative values (exponents) representing units of times are meaningful. In those cases, a value of –1 might represent 1 year before a particular time when an estimate or census occurred.
  • Choosing the appropriate labels and tick marks on the axes is important for correctly displaying a graph. Make sure you select intervals that can help differentiate among points but still allow for the display of every point in the data.
  • When trying to compare values that are in decimal form and scientific notation, first convert all the values into one form or the other.
  • Values written in scientific notation can be used to solve problems in context just like values in decimal form.
